turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: No...

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: We can do it!

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: Hello.

turns.speaker: RICKY
turns.text: You the bug lady, right?

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: You guys have done a nice job.  How bout five dollars?

turns.speaker: RICKY
turns.text: That's it?

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: You sure you didn't see one of these?

turns.speaker: RICKY
turns.text: Gross. What is it?

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: An "Ootheca". An eggcase. It probably had more, uh "weirdbugs" inside.

turns.speaker: RICKY
turns.text: No way. I see one of those, I'd puke.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: Siri, sandblast that thing. It looks like Trump Tower.  Those mounds are supposed to be made of dirt and excretions...

turns.speaker: SIRI
turns.text: Just like Trump Tower, then.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: ...as long as they're ready for the opening I don't care, just tell them that.

turns.speaker: SIRI
turns.text: I'm on it.  Don't worry.  Look, Susan...I don't mean to pry, but... I kinda overheard you and Peter.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: Watch your step, Siri.  Your grant could be on the line here.

turns.speaker: SIRI
turns.text: I just...well, I had this cousin in Delhi.  She was having problems, too. She, ah...

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: SIRI
turns.text: She used a baster.

turns.speaker: SIRI
turns.text: Not a big one.  I mean, it was like a turkey baster.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: Oh, Jesus.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: What's this?

turns.speaker: SIRI
turns.text: Oh, right... They been here since noon. I told them you're real busy.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: I'm gonna pull it out and I want you to pin it down, okay?

turns.speaker: SIRI
turns.text: What is it?

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: I have no idea.  Are you ready?

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: It bit you.

turns.speaker: SIRI
turns.text: No shit.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: This wing configuration. I've never...

turns.speaker: SIRI
turns.text: Fuck! It broke the skin...

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: And they're not fully developed.  This thing's not even an adult.

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: My God.

turns.speaker: SIRI
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: SIRI
turns.text: That's impossible.  Insects don't...

turns.speaker: SUSAN
turns.text: I know.  Help me get a sample.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Oh, my!

turns.speaker: BUSTER
turns.text: Sorry, didn't mean to startle you. You didn't give me a chance to knock.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Guess you can tell from my reaction, I'm not all that used to visitors out here. What can I do for you?

turns.speaker: BUSTER
turns.text: I was just wondering if you happen to know anything about Paul Sheldon.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: What do you want to know?

turns.speaker: BUSTER
turns.text: Anything you can tell me might help.

turns.speaker: BUSTER
turns.text: Excuse me, that's not exactly the kind of information I was after. You see, he's been missing for quite some time now, and...

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: I know. It's so upsetting. I'm his number-one fan...I've got all his books, every sentence he ever put down. I'm so proud of my Paul Sheldon collection...  ...here I am, prattling on and my manners have just flown away. I haven't invited you in. Please.

turns.speaker: BUSTER
turns.text: Thank you.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: God told me, since I was his number- one fan, that I should make up new stories as if I was Paul Sheldon. So, went to town. And I bought a typewriter. And paper to type on. The same kind Paul Sheldon used. And I turned the guest bedroom into a writing studio. Would you like to see it?

turns.speaker: BUSTER
turns.text: Sure.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: It's right this way.

turns.speaker: BUSTER
turns.text: Well...  ...maybe it takes time to get the hang of it.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: I could give you a couple of hundred pages of mine, and you could tell me what you think.

turns.speaker: BUSTER
turns.text: I'm not much of a critic.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Well, I just thought--oh, look at me. You'd think I'd never had a house guest before. Would you like something to drink?

turns.speaker: BUSTER
turns.text: Sure.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: How does a nice cup of cocoa sound?

turns.speaker: BUSTER
turns.text: Sounds good.

turns.speaker: BUSTER
turns.text: Must get lonely, living out here all by yourself.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: I always say if you can't enjoy your own company, you're not fit company for anyone else.

turns.speaker: BUSTER
turns.text: You got a point there...

turns.speaker: BUSTER
turns.text: Thanks, Miz Wilkes, but I don't want to take up any more of your time. I best be going.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: But you didn't even taste your cocoa.

turns.speaker: BUSTER
turns.text: If you don't mind, perhaps I could pay you another visit sometime.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: I'd be delighted. Now that you know the way...

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Shhh... we're just outside Silver Creek.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: How long...?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: You've been here two days. You're gonna be okay.  My name is Annie Wilkes and I'm--

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: --my number one fan.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Here.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: What are they...?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: They're called Novril--they're for your pain.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Shouldn't I be in a hospital?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: The  blizzard was too strong. I couldn't risk trying to get you there. I tried calling, but the phone lines are down.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Your legs just sing grand opera when you move, don't they?  It's not going to hurt forever, Paul, I promise you.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Will I be able to walk?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Of course you will. And your arm will be fine, too. Your shoulder was dislocated pretty badly, but I finally popped it back in there.  But what I'm most proud of is the work I did on those legs. Considering what I had around the house, I don't think there's a doctor who could have done any better.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: No, it wasn't a miracle at all... in a way, I was following you.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Following me?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Well, it wasn't any secret to me that you were staying at the Silver Creek, seeing as how I'm your number- one fan and all. Some nights I'd just tool on down there, sit outside and look up at the light in your cabin--  and I'd try to imagine what was going on in the room of the world's greatest writer.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Say that last part again, I didn't quite hear--

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Don't move now--wouldn't want to hurt this neck--  Well, the other afternoon I was on my way home, and there you were, leaving the Lodge, and I wondered why a literary genius would go for a drive when there was a big storm coming.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: I didn't know it was going to be a big storm.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Lucky for you, I did.  Lucky for me too. Because now you're alive and you can write more books. Oh, Paul, I've read everything of Yours, but the Misery novels...

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: You're very kind...

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: And you're very brilliant, and you must be a good man, or you could never have created such a wondrous, loving creature as Misery Chastain.  Like a baby.  All done.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: When do you think the phone lines'll be back up? I have to call my daughter, and I should call New York and let my agent know I'm breathing.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: It shouldn't be too much longer.  Once the roads are open, the lines'll be up in no time. If you give me their numbers, I'll keep trying them for you.  Could I ask you a favor?  I noticed in your case there was a new Paul Sheldon book and...  and I wondered if maybe...

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: You want to read it?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: If you wouldn't mind.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: I have a hard and fast rule about who can read my stuff at this early stage--only my editor, my agent, and anyone who saves me from freezing to death in a car wreck.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: You'll never realize what a rare treat you've given me.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: What's your new book called?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: I don't have a title yet.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: What's it about?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: It's crazy, but I don't really know, I mean I haven't written anything but "Misery" for so long that--you read it you can tell me what you think it's about. Maybe you can come up with a title.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Oh, like I could do that?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: But what?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Nothing.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: No, what is it?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Oh, it's ridiculous, who am I to make a criticism to someone like you?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: I can take it, go ahead.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Well, it's brilliantly written, but then everything you write is brilliant.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Pretty rough so far.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: The swearing, Paul.  There, I said it.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: The profanity bothers you?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: It has no nobility.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Well, these are slum kids, I was a slum kid, everybody talks like that.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Oh, I'm sorry. I didn't mean to wake you.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: It's fine.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: They had it at the store, Paul, there was a whole batch of them there. As soon as I saw it, I slammed my money down. I got the first copy.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Then the roads are open...

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: The one to town is, but that's about it. I called the hospital and talked to the head orthopedic surgeon. I told him who you were and what had happened. He said as long as there's no infection, you're not in any danger, and as soon as the road to the hospital is open, they'll send an ambulance for you.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: The phones are working?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Well, mine's still out. But the ones in town were working just fine. I called that agent of yours.  Oh, Paul, I peeked at the very beginning.  What a wonderful first page--just to read the name Misery Chastain...

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: My daughter must be going nuts.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: ...it's like a visit from my oldest, dearest friend.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: I was supposed to be home for her birthday three days ago.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Your agent said she would tell her you were okay. But I'm afraid you'll have to wait until tomorrow if you want to speak to her yourself.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: I made you my speciality--scrambled eggs a la Wilkes. And I'm on page 75.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: I guess that means it's okay.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: No. No, it isn't, it's--  --oh pooh, I can't think of any words. Would "great" be insulting?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: I can live with "great."

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: I don't mean to pry, but I've read in two magazines now where you were seeing this model who does those disgusting jeans commercials. And I said it can't be true. Paul Sheldon would never waste his time with a trampy woman like that.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Well, you can't believe everything you read in magazines.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: I knew it. I knew it wasn't true. Boy, how do they get away with printing stuff like that?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: You'd be amazed at what some people will believe.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Thank you so much.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: My pleasure.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: I thought it was time you two should meet. Paul, say hello to my favorite beast in all the world, my sow, Misery.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Misery?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Yes. I told you I was your number- one fan.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: I'm getting to believe you.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: This farm was getting kind of dreary, what with just the few cows and chickens and me--  But when I got Misery here, everything Changed--she just makes me smile so.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: She's a fine... uh... pig is what she is...

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: I'm on page three-hundred now, Paul, and it's better than perfect--it's divine. What's the ceiling that dago painted?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: The Sistine Chapel?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Yeah, that and Misery's Child--those are the only two divine things ever in this world...

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: For a while I thought I might go crazy.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: I know how that can be.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: I don't know about you, but what I did to get through it was I dove into work--days, nights--night shifts can be lonely at a hospital. I did a lot of reading. That was hen I first discovered Misery. She made me so happy. She made me forget all my problems.  'Course, I suppose you had a little something to do with that too.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: I just kept reading them over and over. I know when I finish this one-- and I've only got two chapters to go-- I'll just turn right to the front page and start reading it again.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Done?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Yeah, thanks.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: No problem.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Don't get me wrong. I'm not against marriage per se. But it would take a pretty special guy to make me want to go down the aisle again.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Well, it's not something you should enter into lightly.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: It boils down to respect. People just don't respect the institution of marriage any more. They have no sense of real commitment.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: I'd love to stay here and chat, but I'm right at the end and I gotta find out what happens.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Well, I hope you like it.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Of course I'll like it. Misery's about to have her child. What's it gonna be, a boy or a girl? Ooh, don't tell me.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: You...you dirty bird. She can't be dead. Misery Chastain cannot be dead! How could you?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Annie, in 1871, women often died in childbirth, but her spirit is the important thing, and Misery's spirit is still alive--

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: I DON'T WANT HER SPIRIT! I want HER! And you MURDERED her!

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: I DIDN'T...

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Then who did?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: No one--she just died--she slipped away, that's all.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: She slipped away? She slipped away? She didn't just slip away. You did it. You did it. You did it. You did it. You murdered my Misery.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: What are you doing on the floor?  It's my fault. If I'd had a proper hospital bed, this never would have happened. Here, let me help you back in.  I know this hurts, but it'll only take a few seconds. There you go. Comfy?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Perfect.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: You're such a kidder. I have a big surprise for you. But first there's something you must do.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: I don't suppose I could have a little snack while I wait for the surprise?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: I'll get you everything you want, but you must listen first. Sometimes my thinking is a little muddy, I accept that. It's why I couldn't remember all those things they were asking me on the witness stand in Denver.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: But this time I thought clearly. I asked God about you and God said "I delivered him unto you so that you may show him the way."

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Show me the way?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: You want me to burn my book?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: You want me to burn my book?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: I know this may be difficult for you, but it's for the best.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: This isn't difficult, my agent's made dozens of copies. There's gonna be an auction on this, and every publishing house in New York is reading it now. So if you want me to burn it, fine. You're not ridding the world of anything.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Then light the match, Paul.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: No big deal.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: So you've indicated. Do it.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: I know this is the only copy, Paul. When you were twenty-four you wrote your first book and you didn't make a copy, because you didn't think anybody would take it seriously. But they did. And ever since you've never made any copies because you're superstitious--it's why you always come back to the Silver Creek Lodge. You told that story to Merv Griffin eleven years ago.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: You know, Annie, this book never would have survived without you. When it gets to new York, there will be a big auction, and whatever it brings we can split.  God knows you're entitled to it.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Oh, Paul. This isn't about money. It's about decency and purity. It's about God's values.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: You're right. You're right. I don't know what I was thinking. I'll tell you what. It doesn't have to be published. Nobody ever has to see it. I'll just keep it for myself. No one will ever have to know it exists.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: As long as it does exist, your mind won't ever be free. I think you should light the match, Paul.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: I do believe the winters are getting shorter and shorter every year. People say it has something to do with the ozone layer. What do you think?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: I don't know.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Yeah, well, it's a theory. Here's your Novril.  How does tuna casserole sound for dinner?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Great.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: See, isn't this nice?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Great. I've always wanted to visit the other side of the room.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: And look what I've got for you. An electric razor so you can shave yourself now.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: If I knew this was gonna be the surprise, you could've gotten me to burn all my books.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Now don't josh. This is a very big day for you, Paul. Here. You just sit tight, and I'll set everything up.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Set what up?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: That's the big surprise. Your new studio--after all, writers do need a place to work.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Work? You mean write? What in the world do you think I'd write?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Oh, but Paul!  I don't think, I know! Now that you've gotten rid of that nasty manuscript, you can go back to doing what you're great at--  --you're going to write a new novel-- your greatest achievement ever-- Misery's Return.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Misery's Return?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: I know you didn't mean it when you killed her, and now you'll make it right.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Yes. It will be a book in my honor. For saving your life and nursing you back to health. I'll be the first one to read it.  Oh, Paul, you're going to make me the envy of the whole world...

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: You just expect me to whip something off, that it?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: I expect nothing less than your masterpiece.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: You do understand that this isn't the ordinary way books get written-- I mean, some people might actually consider this an oddball situation.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: I guess you don't get bothered by neighbors much.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Don't worry about that. You'll have total solitude so you can concentrate on your work.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Great.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: And I got a great deal on this fifty- pound clunker--on account of it's missing an "n." I told the saleslady "n" was one of the letters in my favorite writer's name.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: It's two of the letters in my favorite nurse's name, Annie.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: You--fooler...!  Did I do good?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: You did great, except there's just one little thing--I can't work with this paper. It's Corrasable Bond, it smudges. Maybe you could go back into town and bring me some white, long-grained mimeo.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: But mine cost the most so I don't see how it could smudge.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: C'mere, I'll show you.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Well, it does smudge after all--isn't that fascinating?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: I thought you'd be interested. I'd like you to be in on everything, Annie. Not just the finished book, but how it's written.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Thank you for thinking of me.  Anything else I can get while I'm in town? Any other crucial requirements that need satisfying? Would you like a tiny tape recorder? Or maybe a handmade set of writing slippers?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: No, just the paper will be fine.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Are you sure? 'Cause if you want, I'll bring back the whole store for you.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Annie, what's the matter?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: What's the matter? I'll tell you what's the matter. I go out of my way for you. I do everything to try and make you happy. I feed you, I clean you, I dress you. And what thanks do I get? "You bought the wrong paper, Annie. I can't write on this paper, Annie." Well, I'll get your stupid paper, but you just better start showing me a little more appreciation around here, Mister Man.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Paul, you're dripping with perspiration, your color is very hectic--what have you been doing?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: You know goddamn well what I've been doing--I'VE BEEN SITTING HERE SUFFERING. I need my pills.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Poor dear... Let's get you back in bed and I'll get them for you.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: I want my pills NOW!

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: It'll only take a second.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: I want my pain to go 'way, Annie-- make it go 'way, please Annie--  --please...

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Here, in case you think of any ideas.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Yeah, well I wouldn't expect too much.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Don't be silly. You'll be brilliant. Think of me as your inspiration.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: I'm sorry, Paul. This is all wrong, you'll have to do it over again.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: What? What happened to "I'll treasure whatever you do?"

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Paul, it's not worthy of you. Throw it all out except for the part of naming that gravedigger after me. You can leave that in.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: I really value your criticism, but maybe you're being a little hasty here.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Paul, what you've written just isn't fair.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: --not fair?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: That's right--when I was growing up in Bakersfield, my favorite thing in all the world was to go to the movies on Saturday afternoons for the chapter plays...

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: --cliff-hangers--

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: I know that, Mister Man--they also call them serials. I'm not stupid, you know.  Anyway, my favorite was Rocket Man, and once it was a no-brakes chapter, the bad guys stuck him in a car on a mountain road and knocked him out and welded the doors shut and tore out the brakes and started him to his death and he woke up and tried to steer and tried to get out, but the car went off a cliff before he could escape and it crashed and burned and--I was so upset and excited and the next week you better believe I was first in line and they always start with the end of the last week and there was Rocket Man trying to get out, and here came the cliff and JUST BEFORE the car went off he jumped free and all the kids cheered--  --but I didn't cheer, I stood right up and started shouting, "This isn't what happened last week--have you all got amnesia?--THEY JUST CHEATED US--THIS WASN'T FAIR--"

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: "HE DIDN'T GET OUT OF THE COCKADOODIE CAR!"

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: They always cheated like that in cliff--  --chapter plays.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: But not you. Not with my Misery. Remember, Ian did ride for Dr. Cleary at the end of the last book, but his horse fell jumping that fence and Ian broke his shoulder and his ribs and lay there all night in the ditch so he never reached the doctor, so there couldn't have been any "experimental blood transfusion" that saved her life. Misery was buried in the ground at the end, Paul, so you'll have to start there.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: What's the matter, Paul? You haven't written a word.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: I can't write this anymore.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Don't be silly. Of course you can.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: I'm telling you, I can't.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: You can--you have the "gotta"--

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: The what?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: The "gotta." Remember, you talked about it in Playboy magazine. You said there's a million things you can't do in this world; you can't hit a curve ball, you can't fix a leaky faucet or make a marriage work-- but there's one thing you always have, and that's the power of the "gotta."

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: I said that?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: You said you can make it so they gotta turn the page. You know, "I 'gotta' know will she live," "I 'gotta' know will he catch the killer." "I gotta see how this chapter ends." You said it. I don't usually buy that magazine. I only got it, 'cause they were interviewing you.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: What about a bee...?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Nothing.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Well, is it fair? Should I keep going?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: You better. Oh, Paul, when Ian realized that the reason they'd buried Misery alive was because the bee sting had put her in that temporary coma--

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: I've known from the very first book that Misery had to be born of nobility and I was right!

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Yeah, yeah...

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Oh, Paul, can I read each chapter when you finish? I can fill in the "n"s.  Will she be her old self, now that Ian has dug her out, or will she have amnesia...?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: ...have to wait.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Will she still love him with that special perfect love?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Have to wait.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Not even a hint?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Misery's alive! Misery's alive. Oh, it's so romantic--this whole house is going to be filled with romance. I'm going to put on my Liberace records--  --you do like Liberace, don't you?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Whenever he played Radio City, who do you think was right there in the front row?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: I'm going to play my records all day

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: To celebrate Misery's return. I couldn't have done it without you.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Oh, Paul. It would be an honor.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: I hope you like it.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: It looks wonderful. And so do you.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Oh...

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: I've never had meatloaf this good, what do you do to it?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: My secret is I only use fresh tomatoes, never canned. And to give it that little extra zip, I mix in some Spam with the ground beef.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Oh.  You can't get this in a restaurant in New York.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Annie, I think we should have a toast.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: A toast?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Yes, to Misery. Let me pour you some more wine.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: To Misery.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Wait, let's do this right. Do you have any candles?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Oh, I don't know. I think so. I'll go look.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Did you study decorating, or do you just have a flair?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Oh, you. I just picked things up over the years.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Well, it certainly says you.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: You really think so?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Absolutely. Listen, if you can't find any, it's okay. I just thought it might be nice.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Are you kidding? If anyone ever told me that one day I'd be having a candlelit dinner with Paul Sheldon in my own house, I woulda checked both legs to see which one was being pulled. Will this do?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: It's perfect.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Oh, God, what have I done? I'm so sorry, Paul. I ruined your beautiful toast. Will you ever forgive me? Here, let me pour another one.  Can we pretend this never happened? To Misery?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: To Misery.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Paul, this is positively the best Misery you've ever written.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: I think you're right.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Annie, what is it?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: The rain... sometimes it gives me the blues.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: When you first came here, I only loved the writer part of Paul Sheldon. But now I know I love the rest of him too. As much as Misery loves Ian.  I know you don't love me--don't say you do--you're a beautiful, brilliant, famous man of the world; and I'm...not a movie star type. You'll never know the fear of losing someone like you if you're someone like me.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Why would you lose me?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: The book is almost finished. Your legs are getting better. Soon you'll be able to walk. You'll be wanting to leave.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Why would I want to leave? I like it here.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: That's very kind of you, but I'll bet it's not altogether true.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: It is.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Paul, I know you've been out.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: You've been out of your room.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: No, I haven't.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Paul, my little ceramic penguin in the study always faces due south.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: I don't know what you're talking about.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Now don't fuss, Paul.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Why would I run away? I'm a writer, Annie--it's all I am--and I've never written this well--even you said that this is my best, didn't you?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Paul, don't you think it's time for you to start writing again? It's been over a week.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: I don't know, it's weird, but a couple of broken bones hasn't done a lot for my creative juices. Get the fuck out of here.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Don't talk to me like that.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Why, what are you going to do?  Kill me? Take your best shot.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Why are you so mean, Mister you'd-be- dead-in-the-snow-if-it-wasn't-for- me?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Oh, no reason, you keep me prisoner, you make me burn my book, you drive a sledgehammer into my ankles...

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: I'll drive a sledgehammer into your man-gland if you're not nicer--

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Be my guest.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: That's disgusting.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: I know you do. I love you too, Annie.  And you're right. We are meant to be together. And I know we must die. But it must be so that Misery can live. We have the power to give Misery eternal life. We must finish the book.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: But the time is now. Soon others will come.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: It's almost done. By dawn we'll be able to give Misery back to the world.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Oh, Paul. It's beautiful.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Three more chapters to go.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: The stranger staying at the Inn, is he someone from Misery's past?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Maybe.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: This is so exciting. It's Windthorne, her first love, right?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Maybe. Are you ready for the next chapter?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: It WAS Windthorne. I knew it--what does that do to her love for Ian?--  --of course, if she hadn't thought Windthorne was murdered she never would have fallen in love with Ian in the first place.  Sorry, it's just that this is so wonderful.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: I'm glad you like it.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Paul, this will be our legacy.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: It will.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Oh, Paul. I'm dying. Does she wind up with Ian or Windthorne? You have to tell me.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: You'll know very soon. I'm starting the last chapter. And when I finish, I want everything to be perfect. I'll require three things.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: What things?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: You don't know?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: I was fooling, silly.  You need a cigarette, because you used to smoke but you quit except when you finish a book, and you just have one, and the match is to light it. And you need one glass of champagne.  Dome Pear-igg-non.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: Dome Pear-igg-non it is.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Yes, Paul.

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: I'm almost done.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Oh, Paul, this is so romantic. Ian and Windthorne dueling for the right to Misery's hand. Does Ian win? Oh, don't me. It's Windthorne, right?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: You'll know everything in a minute. Get the champagne.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Ahh!!!

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Did I do good?

turns.speaker: PAUL
turns.text: You did perfect. Except for one thing. This time we need two glasses.

turns.speaker: VIRGINIA
turns.text: We actually got a phone call. Busy morning.

turns.speaker: BUSTER
turns.text: Work, work, work.  Virginia? When was that blizzard?

turns.speaker: VIRGINIA
turns.text: Four or five days ago. Why?

turns.speaker: BUSTER
turns.text: Virginia, when you're in this car, you're not my wife, you're my deputy.

turns.speaker: VIRGINIA
turns.text: Well, this deputy would rather be home under the covers with the Sheriff.

turns.speaker: BUSTER
turns.text: Stop--stop right here.

turns.speaker: VIRGINIA
turns.text: What? What is it?

turns.speaker: VIRGINIA
turns.text: Could be the weight of the snow.

turns.speaker: BUSTER
turns.text: Could be--or a rotten branch or a mountain lion could have landed on it. Could be a lot of things.

turns.speaker: VIRGINIA
turns.text: You really think Sheldon's out there?

turns.speaker: BUSTER
turns.text: Hope not--if he is, he's dead. Let's go to the newspaper office.

turns.speaker: VIRGINIA
turns.text: Here's the list of all Sheldon's credit charges. Nothing after the Silver Creek.  Any calls?

turns.speaker: BUSTER
turns.text: Just from his agent.

turns.speaker: VIRGINIA
turns.text: You don't think he's dead, do you?

turns.speaker: BUSTER
turns.text: He might well be. But not the way they say. He didn't crawl out of that car by himself. You saw those dents on the door--someone pulled him out.

turns.speaker: VIRGINIA
turns.text: It was an old car--those dents could have been there forever.

turns.speaker: BUSTER
turns.text: There's two kinds of people that drive around in old cars: the ones that can't afford new ones, and the ones who wouldn't give 'em up for anything in the world. That second bunch don't drive around with twenty- five-year-old dents.

turns.speaker: BUSTER
turns.text: Hey, Jim, what's doing? Uh-huh... uh- huh... Jim, we've been over this. If you're gonna have benches in front of your store, people are gonna sit on them. I don't like him either, but I'm not going to come over there and tell him to move. Give my best to Denise. Bye.

turns.speaker: VIRGINIA
turns.text: Well, whoever she is, she sure likes to read a lot.

turns.speaker: BUSTER
turns.text: Virginia, I'm flattered you think I got that much energy. I just figured if I can't find Paul Sheldon, at least I can find out what he wrote about.

turns.speaker: VIRGINIA
turns.text: What do you expect to find? A story about a guy who drove his car off a cliff in a snowstorm?

turns.speaker: BUSTER
turns.text: Now, you see, it's that kind of sarcasm that's given our marriage real spice.

turns.speaker: BUSTER
turns.text: "There is a justice higher than that of man. I will be judged by Him."

turns.speaker: VIRGINIA
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: BUSTER
turns.text: They're hauling Misery into court.

turns.speaker: VIRGINIA
turns.text: That's nice.

turns.speaker: BUSTER
turns.text: "There is a justice higher than that of man--I will be judged by Him."

turns.speaker: BUSTER
turns.text: Just leave it, all right?

turns.speaker: VIRGINIA
turns.text: Oh, I like that tone.

turns.speaker: BUSTER
turns.text: How many times do I have to tell you-- I have a system here.  Where the hell is that thing?

turns.speaker: VIRGINIA
turns.text: What thing?

turns.speaker: BUSTER
turns.text: That thing.  Here it is. Right where it's supposed to be.

turns.speaker: VIRGINIA
turns.text: What is it?

turns.speaker: BUSTER
turns.text: I'm not sure. Maybe nothing.

turns.speaker: VIRGINIA
turns.text: It's good you found it.

turns.speaker: BUSTER
turns.text: There's that spice again.

turns.speaker: SINDELL
turns.text: I'm a literary agent, and I feel like a fool calling you, but I think one of my clients, Paul Sheldon, might be in some kind of trouble.

turns.speaker: BUSTER
turns.text: Paul Sheldon? You mean Paul Sheldon the writer?

turns.speaker: SINDELL
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: BUSTER
turns.text: He's your client, huh?

turns.speaker: SINDELL
turns.text: Yes, he is.

turns.speaker: BUSTER
turns.text: People sure like those Misery books.

turns.speaker: SINDELL
turns.text: I'm sure you know Paul's been going to the Silver Creek Lodge for years to finish his books.

turns.speaker: BUSTER
turns.text: Yeah, I understand he's been up here the last six weeks.

turns.speaker: SINDELL
turns.text: Not quite. I just called, and they said he checked out five days ago. Isn't that a little strange?

turns.speaker: BUSTER
turns.text: I don't know. Does he always phone you when he checks out of hotels?

turns.speaker: SINDELL
turns.text: No, no, of course not. It's just that his daughter hasn't heard from him, and when he's got a book coming out, he usually keeps in touch. So when there was no word from him...

turns.speaker: BUSTER
turns.text: You think he might be missing?

turns.speaker: SINDELL
turns.text: I hate that I made this call--tell me I'm being silly.

turns.speaker: SINDELL
turns.text: I appreciate that. Thanks a lot.

turns.speaker: BUSTER
turns.text: G'bye, Ms. Sindell.
